If you can't bring youself to ride it, simply drive up as far as your vehicles clearance will allow.  Normally, I don't get too excited about old railroad beds, but this one has reverted to true singletrack, the scenery is spectacular, even by Colorado standards, and the occasional interpretive signs are fun to read.  You even get a couple of alpine lakes.  This is the best place to soak up the environment, get some exercise, and get an interesting history lesson all at the same time.
data.directions: Go south of Leadville on US24 for 3.5 miles and turn West on 300.  Turn Right on CR 5.  Turn left at 1.9miles (follow the Turquoise Lake sign).  After another 3.5 miles, the road splits.  Take the left split and park and ride (you can also drive further up the dirt road and park at one of the pullouts further up--this will shorten your ride and get you to the singletrack quicker.)  Trails Illustrated maps 109, 126, and 127 can be helpful.  Combine with a loop around Turquoise Lake for an epic ride.

data.name: Deer Haven Ranch
data.description:
Deer Haven Ranch is a 5,000 acre Bureau of Land Management recreation area that excludes all motorized vehicles, allowing only users on foot, horse and mountain bike. The ranch has a growing network of over 15 miles of double track and single track trails. Terrain is characterized by moderately rolling meadows and forests with several gulches that host numerous rock outcroppings and overlooks of the nearby Wet Mountains, Pikes Peak and Sange de Cristo Mountains.

The double track is a series of old ranch roads that crisscross the entire ranch. A growing network of singletrack constructed by the Bureau of Land Management, a local horse riding advocacy group and users offer a variety of fun rewarding trails. HOWEVER, many of the trails are degrading due to lack of use. Several of the trails are simply being over taken by the surround vegetation. See photos. Regardless, the trails offer a variety of smooth and fast, to moderately technical rocky sections. While there is evidence of illegal motorized use, the area has not seen the abuse by motorized vehicles that most trails in the area has. Deer Haven Ranch is great for long, fun rides, and with some attention, has the potential to be a world class riding destination. There is something for everyone here, please check it out. The ranch needs your love.
data.directions: From US 50 and CO Highway 9, 9.7 miles west of CaÃ±on City, CO head north for 9 miles. Turn right onto High Park Road (CR 11) for 5.3 miles. Turn right onto CR 69 and travel for 0.8 miles, turning right onto Thompson Mountain Road. Travel through a gate and to a large parking area and trailhead at 0.7 miles.

data.name: Eagle Vail Trail
data.description: A rolling single track that has a few good ascents that will get your heart beating, and some fun turns that will get technical at the very end of the trail.  There are some areas where the trail gets very narrow as the tree growth continues to reach out towards this new trail.  Typical mountain trail with roots and loose soil making some areas more technical than they should be.
data.directions: Turn off of Highway 6 in Eagle Vail onto Eagle Road.  Follow road past police station and turn right onto Eagle Drive.  Park at the first parking lot on the right, and then bike up Eagle Drive to the Cul de Sac (about 10 minutes).  Singletrack starts here and winds through an aspen grove to the junction with Pauley's Plunge.  Turn right at this junction and ride downhill on the last bit of Pauley's until you reach a footbridge at the golf course.  From here you will see a sign pointing uphill and to the left for the eagle Vail trail.  Continue riding until you filter out onto the road about 3 miles later.  Ride road east along Deer Blvd and Stone Creek Dr until you reach your car at the parking lot on Eagle Dr.

data.name: Paulie's Plunge
data.description: Paulie's Plunge connects the middle of Cinch road at Beaver Creek to the Eagle-Vail Trail near the top of Eagle Drive. It's best ridden from top to bottom. The upper section is steep, rooty, and surrounded by a beautiful aspen grove. After crossing a bridge, the middle section not as steep, but is littered with rocky fun along a fast flowing creek. The lower section leaves the creek. It's smooth and fast to the bottom.  This narrow singletrack trail drop ~1300 feet of elevation in 1.9 miles. Paulie's Plunge is also known as Stone Creek #2349. If you ride it up, expect to do some pushing in the upper section, above the bridge.
data.directions:
At the top: Cinch trail, just before the switchbacks. There is a gate.
From the bottom: a parking lot near the top of Eagle Drive.

data.name: Red Canyon Park
data.description: This is an area of jeep roads with a couple ATV tracks thrown in.  The roads are very hilly with lots of little climbs but no extended climbs.  The lack of singletrack is partially compensated for by very cool scenery.
data.directions: Head north out of town on the Shelf Road, signed as Field Avenue in town. Travel 9.2 miles north from the intersection of Field and Central and make a left turn onto Road F24 into Red Canyon Park.  Following the road through some winding turns and past a few picnic areas will lead you to out the other side of the park and into a network of jeep roads and ATV tracks.

data.name: Mount Massive Golf Course and Nordic Center
data.description: During the winter the nordic trails here are open to fat bikes. Note: there is no summer mountain biking available here--this is winter, fat-tired biking ONLY.
data.directions: Mt Massive Golf Course

data.name: West Avon Preserve
data.description:
This is a network of a half dozen all singletrack trail segments.  There are some good climbs and descents. There are plenty of switchbacks, some are broad, some are tight, and some have huge berms, but none are technical and all are ridable.  
This network is on the north side of the freeway with most aspects facing south, so it dries faster than other rides in the Vail Valley, extending the riding season nicely.
data.directions: From I-70, take exit 167.  Go to the roundabout on the north side of the interstate and follow the Nottingham frontage road until it dead ends and the entrance to the trail system is there.

data.name: Road #309
data.description: Road #309 runs from Hwy 285 and into the Fourmile Travel Management area, connecting to a variety of other roads.
data.directions: CO

data.name: Turquoise Lake
data.description: To do this as a loop, you can go either direction around the lake--it just depends on whether you want to do the pavement first and the singletrack last or vice versa.  I perfer to get the pavement out of the way first, which means clockwise.  The singletrack is also funner this direction.  Of course, you don't have to do a loop as the singletrack (counterclockwise) makes a great out and back.  As you head counterclockwise, the singletrack by the campgrounds is smooth and fast (but watch for campers).  The further out you get, the rougher the singletrack gets.  Although there is little elevation change, the elevation and rough tread will make the ride take longer than you might think.  Combine the loop with the Hagerman Tunnel ride for a real epic.
data.directions: From Leadville, head south on US24 3.5 miles.  Turn west on 300.  Go right on CR5.  Go 1.9 miles and turn left, following the signs to Turquoise lake.  Go 1.3 mi and turn right at the sign to Matchless Boat Ramp.  Follow signs toward the boat ram.  After the fork to the boat ramp, take the second right into the parking area closest to the water.  FEE AREA.
data.features: Fat biking allowed in winter, Night riding allowed

data.name: Road #311.D
data.description: Road #311.D is a .6-mile 4x4 spur off of Sevenmile Creek Road that connects to the Davis Meadow Trail. This forms a crucial connector for turning Davis Meadow into a loop.
data.directions: CO

data.name: Davis Meadow
data.description: From the tee where you parked, head SE on the 4x4 road a couple miles until the intersection with Rd 311--turn East on 311.  Bypass Motorized trail 1414 on the right and road 311E on the left.  Go through the cattleguard and proceed another mlle  and look for road 311D on your left.  These 4X4 roads are often sandy and have some short but very steep climbs.  Take 311 D which will soon deadend at a parking area and the start of the singletrack.  5 miles of singletrack will then drop you back at another parking lot at the end of 373A which will deposit you back at your vehicle.  The singletrack starts as a gradual climb on narrow, often overgrown tread, then makes a sharp, rocky,,switchback climb before a series of ups and downs and a drop to an old homestead by a boggy area.  Cross the bog, make the final climb to the top of the ridge, then enjoy a seriously rocky drop back to the road.  Again, this is all crystal clear with the map.
data.directions: From US 24 in Buena Vista, turn East on Main Street then North on Colorado Avenue (aka rd 371).  Cross the Arkansas River then turn Northeast road 375 (about 100 yards before the first tunnel).  Follow this until you see a right turn on Foumile Cutoff Road 375A.  From this point, you will need a high clearance vehicle.  Follow 375A until it tees into 373--take the left fork ont 373 and follow it a couple more miles until you see an option to go straight or turn right.  Park at this tee.  This is all easy to follow if you have Trails Illustrated Map #129 "Buena Vista/Collegiate Peaks."

data.name: Mushroom Gulch / Road #308
data.description: Road #308 runs up Mushroom Gulch past stunning rock formations.
data.directions: CO

data.name: Beaver Creek Ski Resort
data.description: There are tons of trails here but only a few are serviced by the summer lift.  If you are in great shape (or too cheap to buy a ticket), skip the lift and ride up the mountain (all 2000 vertical feet).  The "Blue" trails are the singletrack options and they can be pretty challenging for most riders.  The singletrack was mostly washed out and very rooty and steep in sections.  If you choose the "Green" trails, be prepared to take the road all the way to the bottom.  Overall, not one of the best lift serviced downhills available.  Go to Keystone instead (although the scenery is tough to beat).
data.directions: From Denver, take I-70 West to exit 167, Avon.  Follow the signs to the Beaver Creek Ski resort.  There is no parking once you're up the mountain so be sure to make arrangements.
data.features: Lift service, Night riding allowed, Restrooms

data.name: Road #187
data.description: Road #187 is the start of the Aspen Ridge route on the Buena Vista end, but it continues past the Road #185 turn off towards Aspen Ridge and heads deep into the middle of nowhere, connecting to a complex network of 4x4 roads.
data.directions: CO

data.name: North Lone Pine
data.description: Best ridden as a loop, riding the roads up, and decending the trail.  Climb Deadman Rd. west (left out of parking area) for 0.5 mi. to Killpecker Rd (FR 300).  Take a left on Killpecker Rd. and climb 1 mi. to FR 333.  Take FR 333 to FR 333A.  Ride FR 333A for a very short bit and the Lone Pine TH (953) will be on your left.  Decend on moderate singletrack with some rocks, roots, and creek crossings back to your car.  Multiuse trail.  Some views of Red Feather Lakes area.  N. Lone Pine Trail exends further south uphill from where this description says to access it.  Explore.
data.directions: Take US 287 north from Ft. Collins or south from Laramie, WY to Red Feather Lakes Road (CR 74E).  Go west 24-25 miles to Deadman Road.  Take Deadman Road 4-5 miles to the trailhead on left (well marked).

data.name: A-10
data.description: Alpine doubletrack leading up Arrowhead Mountain from the start at Arrowbahn.  Veer left once you reach the Cresta Rd. bridge (@1.4 mi.) and then ride south once you reach the Arrowhead Mtn. junction (.7 mi).  Ride south through pine and aspen meadow to a saddle with views of Gold Dust Peak (left).  A short hike-a-bike (on the right) will lead you to the trail high-point and the singletrack descent into Homestead.
data.directions: From I-70 Exit 163 take Edwards Access Rd. south to Hwy 6.  Turn left and go @ 1 mile to Miller Ranch Rd. (light) making a left, park @ one of the two schools.  Ride back across the Blue-light bridge and go left at the traffic light, continue riding to Arrowhead (on right) and climb up the road to the base of the chairlift and start of the trail.

data.name: Aspen Ridge / Road #185
data.description: FS/CR185 is a 2 wheel drive road that transitions into a four wheel drive road, and it runs through Aspen Ridge to CR 187. Part of CR185 is necessary for the popular Turret gravel road ride.
data.directions: Spurring off of Ute Trail/CR175
data.features: Fat biking allowed in winter, Night riding allowed

data.name: Arnold Gulch Area
data.description: Arnold gulch is a tight network of trails trails that is open to motorized traffic. Some of the trails are open to atvs and some of them are only open to motorcycles, meaning that there is some sweet singletrack to be had in this trail system!
data.directions: CO

data.name: South Sevenmile Road / #376.B
data.description: South Sevenmile Road is a spur off of Lenhardy Cutoff Road that runs for about 2 miles before dead ending.
data.directions: CO

data.name: Road #373 / #373.A
data.description: Road #373 is a sandy 4x4 road that forms a crucial portion of the Davis Meadows Loop. It can also be worked into a number of other rides.
data.directions: CO

data.name: Road #307
data.description: Road #307 is a 2wd dirt road that connects to Hwy 285 on both ends, and to Rd #187 and Rd #308 along the way.
data.directions: CO

data.name: McGee Gulch / #305
data.description: This dirt road runs 2.7 miles up McGee Gulch, running from Highway 285 to Lenhardy Cutoff.
data.directions: CO
data.features: Fat biking allowed in winter, Night riding allowed

data.name: Swingletrack
data.description: This trail is often simply just called the "connector" trail between Avon and Edwards.  Since a common nickname locally for Singletree is "Swingletree,"  the name "Swingletrack" sounds appropriate (although not official yet).  From Avon, you will climb quickly up a drainage and wind your way through a sage field.  After riding down through some berms, you will climb up through several tight switchbacks until you are even with the powerlines.  Descend from here into Singletree.
data.directions: There are 2 entry points for this trail.  One is at the end of Nottingham road in Avon, and the other is accessed from June Creek Road just after you pass Chaparral Road on your right.

data.name: Road #377
data.description: Road #377 connects off of Road #375. It's a pretty short spur, but has its own name.
data.directions: CO

data.name: Trail #1414
data.description: Trail #1414 is a doubletrack trail open to motorcycles and ATVs as well as mountain bikes. It connects to Sevenmile Creek Road on both ends.
data.directions: CO

data.name: Soapstone Natural Area
data.description:
Soapstone is a brand new trail network owned and managed by the City of Fort Collins. Currently there are 30+ miles of trails when you include the adjacent Red Mountain Open Space (Larimer County), and Big Hole Open Space (Cheyenne) all of which are connected.

A storm chased me out but I was able to do the Mahogany Trail and Mahogany Loop (access from upper lot) -- these are fun and flowy, with less rock than we are used to here in FC. None of the climbs are extended, and each climb seems to top out on a ridge with awesome views to the south and west. Switchbacks are manageable and I did not need to dismount at all during the ride. The loop is about 3.3 miles and the "trail" which takes you to the loop is about 1.8 miles.

I also rode the Canyon trail from Mahogany East -- got about a mile and a half before I had to cruise out to beat a storm, but what I saw of Canyon it is beginner doubletrack (an old service road?) -- a bit sandy in spots, but not rocky. Canyon will connect to Cheyenne Rim, which a Ranger had told me has amazing views.

A route the ranger recommended is (from the lower lot) Cheyenne Rim N to Canyon E to Mahogany S to Pronghorn S. Sounds like a great loop -- that's next for me. You can find a map on the city's natural areas website.
data.directions: Soapstone Prairie Natural Area (25 miles, one way) From Fort Collins take Hwy 1/ Terry Lake Road north, turn left onto County Rd 15 and travel north to Rawhide Flats Road. Turn right (north) onto Rawhide Flats Road and follow it to the Soapstone Prairie Natural Area entrance station.

data.name: Killpecker
data.description: Most people will only be able to ride this trial downhill.  So, after parking at the trailhead climb Deadman Rd. east 2 mi. to Killpecker Rd. (FR 300).  Take a right onto Killpecker Rd. and climb to Elkhord Baldy Rd. (FR 517; another 7 mi.).  Take a left, and ride for another mile to the Killpecker Trail (956) after passing a hiking trail.  Killpecker Trial crosses Killpecker Rd. 3 times and can be accessed at any one of these crossings for a shorter loop.  Enter the trail and find a gnarly rock and root infested downhill in Roosevelt NF.  The trail crosses Killpecker creek, and ofters drop-offs, curvacous singletrack, and rock gardens.  The trail is marked where it crosses Killpecker Rd.  This is a multiuse trail, including ATVs, so decend with caution.  And don't do what the trailname suggests (females excluded).
data.directions: Take US 287 north from Fort Collins, CO or south from Laramie, WY to Red Feather Lakes Road.  Go west 24-25 miles to Deadman Road.  Turn left on Deadman Rd. go another 6-7 miles and the Killpecker Trail parking will be on your left (south).

data.name: Shields Gulch / Road #315
data.description: Road #315 is a 2wd dirt road that runs up the bottom of Shields Gulch from Highway 285. After about 2.5 miles it hits Lenhardy Cutoff Road.
data.directions: CO

data.name: Road #376.A
data.description: Road #376.A is a 4x4 dirt road that connects to the Midland Bicycle Trail and Road #376. Trail #1450.A connects between #376.A and Midland as well. A popular route is to loop this dirt road with the Midland Trail and trail #1450.A.
data.directions: CO
data.features: Fat biking allowed in winter, Night riding allowed

data.name: Pine Creek Trail / #1467
data.description: The Pine Creek trail is about 5 miles long one-way. It runs from the trailhead up to the boundary with the Collegiate Peaks Wilderness. The trail carries on into the wilderness but of course, bikes are not allowed past the wilderness boundary.
data.directions: CO
data.features: Fat biking allowed in winter, Night riding allowed

data.name: June Creek Trail
data.description: Sagebrush-lined singletrack that climbs and descends along the north side of I-70 between Edwards and Avon.  Some steep switchbacks in the beginning are rewarded with fun open descending switches through a sage lined canyon, exiting into open winding singletrack.  Thank You to VVMBA and all the volunteers for their hard work on this and other new trails in Eagle County!
data.directions: From the Edwards exit go North into the Singletree development and continue until just after the community park and take a right on June Creek rd.  Continue through the neighborhood and past a couple of golf holes.  The road will turn uphill to the left and the trailhead is on the right (small wooden fenced entrance).

data.name: Oil Well Flats
data.description:
Oil Well Flats is a brand-new singletrack trail system being built around old 4x4 and doubletrack roads. There's currently over 10 miles of brand-new sweet singletrack to ride, with many more miles already under construction and planned for the future.
This trail system is undoubtedly cross-country oriented, but that doesn't mean it's easy. Some of these trails are rather technical, incorporating many natural rocks and features for a very pedally, technical disposition.
That said, all of the singletrack is superbly designed, contouring with the land and passing by some of the most interesting and scenic features.
Thanks to the unique climate surrounding Canon City, this area stays very dry, even during the winter.
Be sure to bring a camera for all of the fantastic views, and a little suspension for the rocks wouldn't hurt, either.
data.directions: Up County Road 9. See Google Maps Directions.

data.name: Colorado Trail: Clear Creek Thd to Lake View CG / Hwy 82
data.description: The Colorado Trail runs for 13 miles from Clear Creek Road to Hwy 82. It begins by climbing steeply, but then mellows out and flows along until it reaches the shores of Twin Lakes. The trail then circles the lake, rolling very easily along and offering up great views of the mountains.
data.directions: Clear Creek Road
data.features: Fat biking allowed in winter, Night riding allowed, Restrooms
